name: NewYorker
text:
“Why put us here? Once upon a time, bad things going on Above? Disease stuﬀ, war stuﬀ, famine stuﬀ?” Read a short story by George Saunders.
https://t.co/9yPGot6pdt

name: NewYorker
text: "We could be on the cusp of a historic realignment," @Redistrict says, "and the red wall in the South is looking about as vulnerable today as the blue wall was in the days preceding the 2016 election." https://t.co/x8KSJAA5E0

name: NewYorker
text:
As we approach the Bush v. Gore decision’s 20th anniversary, we may be facing a possible repeat of those events—and perhaps a genuine constitutional crisis around the Presidential election.
https://t.co/koYKhRfVl3

name: NewYorker
text: “When we talk to our friends, we don’t need scripts or guidance,” a co-founder of the organization Vote Tripling said. “No matter how hard I try, you’re going to be way better than I am at getting your friends to vote.” https://t.co/D75QWVkOPx

name: NewYorker
text: The Crown Heights bar and restaurant, which offers bottled cocktails to go and seasonal dishes like a duck-and-apple sandwich, hosts everything from clambakes to movie nights to political postcard drives. https://t.co/lL35Wfxvnr

name: NewYorker
text: “When, prior to lunch today, did you last spend time alone with a woman who is not your wife?” Curtis Sittenfeld reads her short story. https://t.co/2walJ7Lf0E

name: NewYorker
text: “When you touched me, I named / the future: Be here. Stay living.” A poem by @ErikaLSanchez. https://t.co/s63re8MLRl

name: NewYorker
text: “Trump can and will ramble on until the very end,” @sbg1 writes, “convinced that the audience is there for whatever he chooses to give it and that, just like their President, they don’t give a shit about the particulars.” https://t.co/QMcnabQvfH

name: NewYorker
text:
The possibility that the Supreme Court may play a decisive role in the upcoming Presidential election revives memories of the Bush v. Gore decision, in 2000.
https://t.co/VLxgFZujIm

name: NewYorker
text:
Charles Bethea recounts a hostile encounter with a Trump supporter at a Joe Biden rally.
https://t.co/m4MHpqFa1l

name: NewYorker
text: “Most stolen-valor cases don’t involve master criminals but, rather, average men who want to be treated as if they were extraordinary.” @rachmonroe on military imposters and the people who track them down. https://t.co/5dhBFWEXht

name: NewYorker
text: Brittany Howard taught herself to play the guitar when she was 11 years old. “I had no options, and I didn’t care about anything else,” she says. https://t.co/wlNIWSJlKi

name: NewYorker
text: Time and again, Joe Biden has turned to a message of bipartisanship when summoning an overarching purpose for his campaign. Can he bring about national unity? https://t.co/xXZt6S76bH

name: NewYorker
text: Jessica Lester insisted she had never had thoughts about harming herself, but police concluded that two gunshots to her head were self-inflicted. What really happened? https://t.co/gtxN6pkRTA

name: NewYorker
text: Stanley Kubrick and Arthur C. Clarke set out to make a new kind of sci-fi. How does their future look now that it’s the past? https://t.co/0FF7AfAFIu

name: NewYorker
text: Did a caricature as crude as Nurse Ratched need to be reclaimed? https://t.co/mgAUsE3uJa

name: NewYorker
text: “I feel like the gentleman on the high wire when he was crossing between the towers of the World Trade Center,” one restaurant owner said. “There’s no net." https://t.co/5uMHgadrLK

name: NewYorker
text: Bullet journalling has taken off on the Internet as a kind of mindfulness-meets-productivity trend that equates organized journaling with an ordered interior life. https://t.co/hrxOxsnrWE

name: NewYorker
text: The new film “Martin Eden”—an adaptation of the novel by Jack London—is an iteration of an old fallacy: the notion that, if a movie’s subject involves intellectual matters, the movie will be intellectually substantial, @tnyfrontrow writes. https://t.co/P4KpkmZ6Ls

name: NewYorker
text:
In the final days of Donald Trump’s 2020 campaign, the President’s glee in slinging hate is equalled by the discomfiting spectacle of thousands cheering him on as he does it, @sbg1 writes.
https://t.co/bcp09JptHQ

name: NewYorker
text: "The bizarre, dysfunctional, and dangerous times we live in have been distilled into a morality play, with a cast of 330 million people," @jelani9 writes. https://t.co/FRIGHmfl1n

name: NewYorker
text:
Election Day is here. Bookmark our live map to follow along with the latest news, updates, and analysis as election results roll in.
https://t.co/OcfRjIjzZ8

name: NewYorker
text: What is America about today? And is it any different from its deeply flawed past? https://t.co/Bnooeb7u0q

text:
Take up knitting, build a lawn chair out of sticks, decide who to vote for, and other ways to pass the time.

name: NewYorker
text:
RT @jelani9: Science is increasingly worried that the virus will become endemic, a persistent threat to our lives. We should have the same concerns about the chaotic forces of Trumpism, even if — maybe especially if — their principal suffers a crushing defeat tonight.

https://t.co/hRKAFGh5F6

name: NewYorker
text: In Pennsylvania, a key battleground state, Republicans could use a delay in counting votes to argue that the election is rigged—and to appoint special electors who could decide the winner. https://t.co/TxBlwd4fnY

name: NewYorker
text:
RT @sbg1: Will it really just be over in a predictable blaze of angry tweets and rally rants?

My diary of Trump’s final days as a candidate: https://t.co/xZIO4Ho64f

name: NewYorker
text: For five years, Republicans have been wearily answering (or dodging) the question of whether they support President Trump. But voters are now asking them something deeper—about what they have actually delivered. https://t.co/JuHz6muLjW

name: NewYorker
text: "I had some considerable difficulties, legally, years ago, and [Donald Trump] was extremely supportive," Conrad Black says. "It is what he does as President in policy terms that is more important, and that’s why I support him." https://t.co/hiEE19eJPu
